children.name: the opinion people have about a person, organization etc
reputation
children.definition: the opinion that people have about a person, organization etc because of what has happened in the past: danh tiếng

children.name: have a good/bad etc reputation
examples: The law firm has an excellent reputation.

children.name: get a reputation
children.definition: alsogain/acquire a reputationformal
examples: Over the years, the company has gained a reputation for making quality products.|I didn’t want to get a reputation as a troublemaker.

children.name: earn/win a reputation
examples: As a young publisher, she earned a reputation for toughness.

children.name: enjoy a reputation
children.definition: have it
examples: The hotel enjoys a good reputation.

children.name: deserve a reputation
children.definition: have earned it
examples: France deserves its reputation for good food.

children.name: live up to its reputation
children.definition: be as good as people say it is
examples: New York certainly lived up to its reputation as an exciting city.

children.name: establish a reputation
children.definition: make people accept that you are good at doing something
examples: By then Picasso was already establishing his reputation as an artist.

children.name: enhance sb’s reputation
children.definition: make it better
examples: The performance enhanced his reputation as one of our most promising young actors.

children.name: build/develop a reputation
examples: Our business has built a reputation for reliable service.

children.name: damage sb’s reputation
examples: She wouldn’t do anything to damage her family’s reputation.

children.name: tarnish sb’s reputation
children.definition: make it worse
examples: His reputation was tarnished by allegations that he had taken bribes.

children.name: destroy/ruin sb’s reputation
examples: The accusation ruined her reputation and cost her the election.

children.name: good/excellent
examples: The university has a very good reputation.

children.name: bad/poor
examples: The city doesn’t deserve its bad reputation.

children.name: a considerable reputation
children.definition: one that is quite important
examples: He was also an historian with a considerable reputation.

children.name: an international/worldwide reputation
examples: The department has a worldwide reputation for its research.

children.name: a formidable reputation
children.definition: one that makes people have a lot of respect for someone or something, or be afraid of them
examples: After the meeting, I understood why he had such a formidable reputation.

children.name: an enviable reputation
children.definition: a good one that others would like to have
examples: The company has established an enviable reputation for quality.

children.name: a well-deserved reputation
examples: Ronaldo’s performances earned him a deserved reputation as a terrific footballer.

children.name: an undeserved reputation
examples: She has an undeserved reputation for being difficult, but really it's just her manner.

children.name: reputation for
examples: Judge Kelso has a reputation for being strict but fair.

children.name: reputation as
examples: In her last job she gained a reputation as a hard worker.

children.name: image
children.definition: the idea that people have about a well-known person, company, or product - use this especially about an idea that is deliberately created through newspaper stories, advertising etc: hình ảnh
examples: image as
Perth is proud of its image as a breeding ground for ‘don’t-take-no-for-an-answer’ entrepreneurs.
image of
attempts to improve the image of the police
be bad/good for somebody’s image :làm xấu/tốt hình ảnh ai
The President’s advisers said it would be bad for his image to be photographed with union leaders.

children.name: a good/positive image
examples: We want to give people a positive image of the town.

children.name: a bad/negative image
examples: It’s difficult to explain why the industry has such a bad image.|Many negative images of women are found in the media.

children.name: a wholesome/clean-cut image
children.definition: morally good and never doing anything bad
examples: The recent scandal has damaged his clean-cut image.

children.name: an upmarket imageBritish English,an upscale imageAmerican English
children.definition: expensive and good quality
examples: The company is trying to promote an upmarket image.

children.name: a downmarket imageBritish English,a downscale imageAmerican English
children.definition: cheap and not good quality
examples: The store has struggled to break away from its downmarket image.

children.name: the traditional image of something
examples: They want to improve the traditional image of English food.

children.name: the popular image of something
examples: The popular image of the spy as a glamorous figure of mystery is far from the reality.

children.name: sb’s/sth’s public image
children.definition: the image that many people have of someone or something
examples: Her public image does not reflect the way she behaves in private.

children.name: sb’s screen image
children.definition: how someone seems in films or on TV
examples: He had cultivated a screen image as a ruthless tough guy.

children.name: a macho image
children.definition: sb’s image as a man who is strong and tough
examples: He was keen to project a macho image in this film.

children.name: have an image
examples: The product has a rather downmarket image.

children.name: create an image
examples: The company is trying to create an image of quality and reliability.

children.name: improve your image
examples: The casino industry was keen to improve its image.

children.name: damage your image
examples: Has this scandal damaged the company’s image?

children.name: live up to your image
children.definition: be like the image you have presented of yourself
examples: He has certainly lived up to his wild rock-star image.

children.name: present/project/promote an image
children.definition: behave in a way that creates a particular image
examples: He presented an image of himself as an energetic young leader.

children.name: cultivate an image
children.definition: try to encourage or develop an image
examples: He was trying to cultivate an image of himself as an intellectual.

children.name: tarnish an image
children.definition: damage it slightly
examples: His behaviour has tarnished the image of the sport.

children.name: clean up your image
children.definition: improve your image after it has been damaged
examples: The pop star promised to clean up his image after he was released from prison.

children.name: lose/shed an image
children.definition: get rid of it
examples: The party struggled to lose its image of being somewhat old-fashioned.

children.name: an image problem
examples: Politicians have an image problem as far as many young people are concerned.

children.name: name
children.definition: the reputation a person or an organization has because of something they do or because of the quality of what they produce, usually when this is good – used especially in the following phrases: tên tuổi
examples: He’s a determined man and he values his good name.
The companyhas a name forreliability.

children.name: a good name
examples: The company wants to maintain its good name.

children.name: a bad name
examples: Most students feel that both boys and girls deserve a bad name if they sleep around.

children.name: have a name
children.definition: for something
examples: They have a name for good quality food.

children.name: make your name
children.definition: alsomake a name for yourself
examples: (= become famous for something )He made a name for himself as a conductor of the Berlin Orchestra.

children.name: clear your name
children.definition: prove that you have not done something bad or illegal
examples: She was determined to clear her name.

children.name: give somebody/something a bad name
children.definition: make someone or something have a bad reputation
examples: A scandal like this could give the university a bad name.

children.name: get a good/bad name
examples: Teenagers tend to get a bad name for being moody.

children.name: standing
children.definition: sb’s reputation and position compared to other people in a group or society, based on other peoples’ opinion of them: chỗ đứng, vị thế
examples: Barb’s work helped to improve her standing with her colleagues.
standing in
The scandal damaged the governor’s standing in the polls.
of high/low standing
a lawyer of high standing
social/moral/professional etc standing
The class system in Great Britain encourages people to be very aware of their social standing.
This legal case is very likely to damage the company’s professional standing.
national/international etc standing
Jacques Tati was a man of international standing in the world of screen comedy.

children.name: prestige
children.definition: the respect and good reputation a person, organization, profession etc has because they have a high position in society, are admired by people etc: thanh thế
examples: prestige of
the prestige of having your work shown at a top London gallery
The king wanted toenhancehisprestigethrough war.
Does Stanford Universitycarrythe sameprestigeas Harvard orYale?
This little-known British firm has nowgainedconsiderableprestige.
the personal prestige attached to owning a large property
The teaching profession has lost the prestige it had in former times.
Hosting the Olympic Games would add to our country’s international prestige.
Becoming a film star confers status, power, prestige and wealth.

children.name: stature
children.definition: a reputation for being very good at sth, very important, or very influential that makes people respect you: tiếng tăm
examples: At that time there were no other universities in England equal in stature to Oxford and Cambridge.
stature as
As he got older, Picasso’s stature as an artist increased
of world/international/national etc stature
a British architect of international stature.

children.name: character
children.definition: the opinion that people have about whether you are a good person and can be trusted: tiếng
examples: A person’s character is very important to me when I decide who I want to work with.

children.name: be of (good/bad) etc character
examples: Her husband was a man of good character, well-liked and respected by his colleagues.

children.name: a manofpreviousgood character
examples: The campaign was accused ofcharacter assassination(= an unfair attack on someone’s character )because of its negative ads.
His defence called several people ascharacter witnesses(= people who think that someone has a good character ).
Mr Wetherby wrote him acharacter reference(= a statement about his good qualities ).

children.name: credibility
children.definition: the quality of deserving to be believed and trusted: sự tín nhiệm

children.name: have some/no/little credibility
examples: By then the president had ceased to have any credibility.

children.name: give somebody/something credibility
examples: There's enough evidence to give credibility to this theory.

children.name: undermine/damage credibility
examples: A number of factors undermine the credibility of these statistics.

children.name: destroy credibility
examples: The scandal nearly destroyed the FBI's credibility.

children.name: establish your credibility
examples: Dave had already established his credibility with the department managers.

children.name: lend credibility to somebody/something
children.definition: make something or someone have more credibility
examples: The evidence lent credibility to their arguments.

children.name: gain credibility
examples: It took many years for these ideas to gain credibility in the science community.

children.name: lose credibility
examples: Both of our major political parties are losing credibility.

children.name: lack/be lacking in credibility
examples: The new regime lacked credibility from the start.

children.name: restore credibility
children.definition: get it back again after it has been damaged
examples: His priority was to restore credibility to his government.

children.name: political/scientific/academic etc credibility
examples: A school's academic credibility often depends on its exam results.

children.name: low credibility
children.definition: little credibility
examples: The organization has had low credibility among teachers.

children.name: great credibility
children.definition: a lot of credibility
examples: He has great credibility in Washington.

children.name: a blow to somebody/something's credibilty
children.definition: something that damages credibility
examples: The case was a severe blow to the administration's credibility.

children.name: damage/undermine sb’s credibility (as sth)
examples: The scandal has damaged his credibility as a leader.

children.name: credibility of
examples: There are serious questions about the credibility of these reports.

children.name: gain/lose credibility
examples: Predictions of economic recovery have now lost all credibility.

children.name: reputable
children.definition: a reputable company or business person has a good reputation and can be trusted: uy tín, có tiếng
examples: We chose that company because we thought they were reputable.

children.name: reputable firm/company/ etc
examples: If you have a burglar alarm fitted, make sure it is done by a reputable company.
If you are going to be out late, book a taxi from a reputable firm.
Most reputable suppliers advertise in Birds magazine.

children.name: a reputable source
examples: Only buy floppy disks that have come from a reputable source.

children.name: prestigious
children.definition: a prestigious organization, event, or product has a reputation of being one of the best of its kind and is highly respected: có uy tín, thanh thế
examples: I am a partner in one of Cleveland’s oldest and most prestigious law firms.
The anxiously awaited invitations to the prestigious end-of-year dance began to arrive.
Women are attaining powerful and prestigious managerial positions.
a prestigious literary award
ahighly prestigiousuniversity

children.name: well thought of
children.definition: be  if a person or their work is well thought of, they have a good reputation for the quality of their work: có tiếng, được quý trọng
examples: Richards is well thought of within his own firm.
Millet’s work is less well thought of today than it was during his lifetime.

children.name: prestige
children.definition: prestige goods, products, services etc cost a lot and have a very good reputation: uy tín
examples: There are always prestige neighbourhoods where only the wealthy or successful can afford to live.

children.name: champagne, caviar, truffles and other prestige goods
to damage the reputation of sb/sth
damage sb’s reputation
children.definition: harm/ hủy hoại danh tiếng ai
examples: If a representative gets drunk at a convention, it may harm their firm’s reputation.

children.name: Sabine was completely loyal to you. She would never do anything to damage your reputation
give sb a bad name
children.definition: give sb/sth a bad name to give a group or place a bad reputation by behaving in an unacceptable way: tạo tiếng xấu cho ai
examples: Students who are rude and scruffy give the school a bad name.
The regular brawling and violence in the bar had given it a bad name.
He was the type of person that gives insurance salesmen a bad name.

children.name: bring sb into disrepute
children.definition: bring sb/sth into disrepute formal to damage the reputation of the organization that you work for or the job that you do by doing sth bad or illegal - use this especially in legal or official contexts: mang tai tiếng, làm mất thanh danh
examples: This is exactly the kind of incident that brings international companies into disrepute.
The officers were charged with bringing the police force into disrepute.

children.name: discredit
children.definition: /bring discredit on to make people stop trusting or believing in sb/sth: làm mất niềm tin/tín nhiệm
examples: There was a plot by certain members of the opposition to discredit the government.
The old leaders were discredited by the massive defeats at Verdun and Flanders.
Through your selfishness, you have brought discredit on yourself and your whole family.

children.name: character assassination
children.definition: characterassassination a cruel and unfair attack on someone’s character: bôi nhọ
examples: All too often politicians discredit themselves by engaging in character assassination.

children.name: slur
children.definition: /stain on sth sth that harms sb’s character, reputation etc in sb’s opinion: dèm pha, làm hoen ố

children.name: a slur/stain on sb’s character/reputation etc
examples: Baker accused the press of casting a slur on his reputation.
He was discharged from the army without a stain on his character.

children.name: smear campaign
children.definition: /whispering campaign an attempt to damage the reputation of a political opponent by secretly spreading false ideas about them, for example by telling a newspaper that they have done bad or dishonest things: chiến dịch bôi nhọ
examples: ▪ Kingsley denies all the rumours, saying he’s the victim of a vicious smear campaign.

children.name: smear campaign/whispering campaign against
examples: ▪ Allegations of instability, untrustworthiness and lack of political judgement - all these were part of the whispering campaign against her.

children.name: stain
children.definition: to damage the good opinion that people have about sb/sth: bôi nhọ, làm nhơ nhuốc, “nhuộm”

children.name: stain sb’s name/honour/reputation etc
examples: Several important politicians have had their reputations stainedbythis scandal.
The country's history is stainedwiththe blood of (= The country is guilty of killing) millions of innocent men and women.

children.name: cast doubt
children.definition: /suspicion onsb/sth

children.name: to make people feel less sure about or have less trust in something or someone
examples: _New evidence has cast doubt on the guilty verdict.
